chapter.title: Goy
chapter.para: You've probably heard the term goy used in reference to non-Jews.

Colloquially, the term goy is used to refer to a non-Jew. Students of Torah generally do not care too much for modern colloquiallisms in their studies. Therefore, we will not be referring to this type of goy. Instead, we will be referrring to the goy found in Torah. This is the goy stam - the plain goy.

In Torah shebikhtav, the term goy seems to have a neutral connotation, where any negativity toward goy would be implied. This may not actually be true, but it seems that way. However, it seems during the time of the Prophets and Writings, goyim started getting a bad wrap for being primarily idol worshippers. This connotation carried over into the Torah sheba'alpeh, where goyim as idolaters were solidified. It is only with other qualifiers that goy changes it's idolater status.

sect1.title: Goy and Am: The Difference
sect1.para: The words goy and am are usually both translated as "people" or "nation" and are seemed to be interchangeable. However, that doesn't seem to be the case. Goy seems to denote something akin to culture and way of life. Am seems to denote physical groups of people that live and interact with one another. Bnei Yisrael is referred to as a holy goy; often translated as holy nation. - הכרמל - מלבים, מאיר ליבוש, 1809-1879

sect1.title: Halacha
sect1.para: A goy cannot envolve himself in Torah study.
A goy cannot keep shabbat. He cannot even rest or take time to rest. He may not create holidays.

listitem.para: "An ox of a Jew which gores an ox of a Canaanite is exempt." They say: whichever way you turn -- if "his neighbor" is meant specifically, an ox of a Canaanite which gores an ox of a Jew should also be exempt; if "his neighbor" is not meant specifically, an ox of a Jew which gores an ox of a Canaanite should also be liable. Rabbi Abahu said: it is written, "He stood and measured the earth; He beheld and drove asunder the nations" -- [God] saw that the Sons of Noah [Gentiles] were not fulfilling the Seven Commandments they accepted upon themselves, and permitted their property to the Jews. Rabbi Jochanan said, it is learnt from here: "He appeared from Mount Paran" -- from Mount Paran [the Giving of the Torah] their property was permitted to the Jews.

blockquote.para: According to what is said in the Gemara, this law applies only to the nations which are not restricted by ways of religions and customs, as the Gemara said of them, "[God] saw that the Sons of Noah [non-Jews] were not fulfilling the Seven Commandments [20] they accepted upon themselves, so He permitted their property to the Jews," as long as they are obliged by these commandments -- therefore, those [non-Jews] who fulfill the Seven Commandments should be treated by us as we are treated by them, and we should not favor ourselves in judgment; now it is unnecessary to specify that this is also the case concerning the nations restricted by ways of religions and customs.

sect1.title: Responsa
sect1.para: Statement: The goy means all non-Jews

Response: The goy is different than other non-Jews. For example the goy cannot give charity to the bnei Yisrael and have a poor bne Yisrael accept it. However, a ben Noach who keeps the sheva mitzvot bnei Noach can give charity and it is received. Therefore, goyim and bnei Noach are not the same.
Statement: The goy is a superset of non-Jews
